content:
re : 4) Is there a way to HIDE the All Mail, Important and Starred folders?

Sounds like you are using gmail and it's an imap account.

If you do not want to see them then do this.

  • Right click on the imap gmail account name in Folder Pane and select 'Subscribe'
  • Select 'All Mail', 'Important' and 'Starred' folders and click on 'Unsubscribe'
  • click on 'OK'

content:
christ1 said
Personally - I put the 'Quick Filter' button onto the 'Unified Toolbar' and then hide the 'Message List Header'

Then you neither have the total message count (unless you turn it on in the Folder Pane Header) nor the selected message count. Eliminating these counters in the Status Bar in TB115 wasn't such a brilliant idea after all.

I enabled the total message count in Folder Pane. Yes, it is pain that you lose the selected number of messages. Keeping the Status Bar is important as it shows the real link when you hover over links - a safety check mechanism. It also acts as a definitive base to the window from a visual design point of view. I think it was a bad decision to remove the counters from the Status bar.

Not sure if you are aware of it but there is an the intention to remove the Status bar as mentioned in this bug report read comment 1: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1847571

content:
Any reason why you need to downgrade? It is possible to do all sorts of modifications enable stuff, disable stuff etc, so maybe it's a simple issue you need to resolve - just ask and I'll try to help. Examples: The Unified Toolbar' is like the old 'Mail Toolbar' you can put all required icons back onto it like 'Write' or 'Tag' or 'Quick Filter' etc. You can choose to see the Message List in the new 'Card View' or the old standard 'Table View'. That is swapped using the new icon located to the right of the 'Quick Filter' button on the new 'Message Lsit Header' toolbar which you can then hide if you not want it.

You can enble the 'Menu Bar'- File, Edit, View etc via the 'Menu app' icon. I've set up info on how to position it at the top. https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/142290

Thunderbird now has more in the Menu to help you sort out spacing and font size in the general UI.

Thunderbird now has more options than before. I've been using it for a while and it's really not that bad once you've tweaked what you prefer.

Otherwise, you would need to : In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application basics' - half way -Profile Folder - click on 'Open Finder' button
  • Exit Thunderbird now.
  • Delete the file called 'compatibility.ini'
  • Uninstall Thunderbird.
  • Get a fresh download from this link - install and it should pick up your profile.
  • http://ftp.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/102.15.1/mac/
  • Choose prefered language eg: 'en-GB' is English British
  • Download and then run 'Thunderbird 102.15.1.dmg'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
You cannot drag and drop a contact from one address book eg: Collected Addresses into a 'Mailing List' in another address book eg: Personal Addresses. But you should be able to drag and drop a contact from one address book eg: Collected Addresses into another address book eg@ Personal Addresses and then drag and drop from 'Personal Address Book' into one of Personal Addresses' Mailing Lists.

This is because a contact has to be in the Address book eg: Personal Addresses before it can get a tag to also appear in one it's Mailing Lists. A 'Mailing List' is like a virtual list, it does not actually exist. It's like a display of a contact in the address book which has had a type of 'tag' applied so you can also see it in a mailing list.

content:
That is addressed in settings>general. Okay, this may sound strange, but here is the real way to set fonts on Thunderbird. And I attached examples of my own setting of Calibri 14 as my default. Here goes: 

- in Tools>settings>general, set your default font.  - then click the advanced button. Notice the drop-down menu at top. It probably says 'latin' or 'other writing systems' - this is IMPORTANT:  - select 'latin from that menu, set your desired font and font size settings, click OK,  - select 'otherwritingsystems' from the drop-down menu and set the IDENTICAL settings to what you did for Latin, and then click OK. In attached screenshots you will see my latin and otherwritingsystem match.  Notice I also set monospace font. - and, if you have account set to compose HTML, then set that in tools>settings>composition to variable-width and medium font. (You would only change the HTML font setting if your intent is for recipient to receive your preferred font - not my personal recommendation.) - Set Sending Format to 'automatic'

With these settings, your compose window and your sent folders will match. And if you don't write HTML (e.g., bold, italic, color), none will be sent . If you do these settings once, your font will always be consistent. This does not protect you from someone sending you a message in some god-awful font with 30 pt size, but this does provide consistency.

content:
My test of the server just came back. https://www.immuniweb.com/ssl/endeavour.servers.prgn.misp.co.uk/UjBgAzQ0/

It would appear that the server is vulnerable to the logjam vulnerability. Thunderbird increased the minimum cypher required in 2048 back when the vulnerability was detected

What this means is you should not be able to connect to the mail server endeavour.servers.prgn.misp.co.uk with a standard Thunderbird security setup using SSL,TLS or STARTTLS

This is the information we used when logjam came around in v38. http://mzl.la/1I90UQy So I suggest you try using the server without any SSL. This may mean the port will be 993.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Toad-Hall said
Do you get any error messages - if yes, what do they say word for word or post an image of error.
A response to this question would be enlightening to all concerned.

johnlerrington1 said
Don't let your anti-virus software scan incoming and outgoing messages.

One of the more remarkable ideas with antivirus products is scanning outgoing mail. The product has scaned your system and can find nothing. So what exactly is it ever going to find leaving a system it has certified clean?

Don't let your anti-virus software scan attachments.

An unfortunate fact of life is what antivirus products excel at is corrupting attachments in email. To scan them, they need to;

  • open the mail
  • detect the attachment boundaries in the text of the email
  • Extract the mime encoded text representation of the attachment from mime encoding back into it's original binary format.
  • Scan the resultant file object they have decoded
  • and for some reason I fail to understand they then try and put humpty together again. Poorly.

If you have no attachment scanning;

  • You select the attachment to save or view.
  • Thunderbird extracts the mime encoded text representation of the file.
  • Decodes it and writes it to disk.

At this time any antivirus product worth it existence will scan the new file, be it in the temp folder or some other saved location and stamp on an virus, long before it can be executed.

Why scan something that will be scanned before you can access it, except to slow down you fetch of mail?

Don't let your anti-virus software intercept your secure connection to the server.

Given that most of the scanning of secure connections uses man-in-the-middle hacking and self signed certificates issued on the fly by the antivirus product, you best really trust them to not be malicious and to not ever be hacked or infected. Despite the fear sold with malware detecting software and email is a text file. SO is fundamentally inert in transit. It is what is done with that text file upon receipt that can lead to issues. Most modern mail application run scripts in the email body. Thunderbird does not. It renders the HTML in the body and even then certain HTML statements are ignored for security reasons. Thunderbird can and will show you the sanitized HTML without ever reaching out to download linked malware via scripts. As attachments only become more than glorified text when you try and do something with them, they to are safe while at rest in your inbox. So really this scanning caper of time consuming and risky in it's own way without any real tangible benefits that I can see.

Remove any add-ons your anti-virus software may have installed in Thunderbird.

Unfortunately none of the anti virus programs that inject their garbage into Thunderbird respect the addons environment. Some do not even bother to have an entry in Thunderbird for the user to disable their offering when everything goes pear shaped, usually every time there is a major upgrade. So yes, you will find support folk suggesting that you disable the virus like approach of modifying applications with untested code changes.

So basically remove all virus protection???

Not at all. Just reigning in some of the excesses that the security vendors like to sell to people in their usual manner of selling fear. I personally use Microsoft Defender, it has no email scanner of any sort. It just monitors the hard disk for changes, something that will occur when you get mail! and when attachments are acted upon.


johnlerrington1 said
but I cant see how to correlate the account number with the account settings in server settings.

It is a little tricky, and needs you to jump through some hoops in the Config Editor.

Open the config editor and look for mail.account.account14.identities. This will give a reference to at least one identity usually in the form idXX with the XX being a number. Perhaps it will be id14 for that account, but it just as easily may not as each account can really have an unlimited number of identities associated with it. Now search for that Id number in the Config Editor and the assorted returned values for the Identity will make it clear which account the number is. With things like reply address and useremail to guide you at least I hope it is clear. Sorry, but I don't have a simpler method.

Personally at this time I would suggest you try the standard diagnostics to see if either troubleshoot mode for Thunderbird or the operating system help alleviate the issue, as that will offer clues as to what may or may not be responsible.

    • Does Thunderbird work as expected in Thunderbird troubleshooting mode?
    • Does Thunderbird work as expected with your OS started in safe mode with Networking.

Instructions for each operating system: Windows 10/11, Windows 8, Windows 7, OSX

content:
Please note the following:

Thunderbird by default does not allow Remote content. So providing you do not switch that off then any image of any size containg remote content - including tiny pixel size things you could not see do not work. Do not enable the option 'Display attachments inline' as a default setting - this is something you may enable if and when you need it and then only for email you know are legit. Do not click on links before you have checked they are correct - always check where they are really pointing to first - hover over link and look in Status Bar for the real link. Do not click and open attachments unless you really know who they came from. Don't let your curiosity get the better of you. I get loads of nefarious people pretending stuff like here is the invoice when I know it's just not true. Delete the email and then compact the folder and the bad stuff is nuked.

All of the above is just basic good practise.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
It's not enough info to just say 'it's not working'.

The text space is for you to offer information about your particular setup such as what OS you use, what version of Thunderbird, whether you use Imap or Pop accounts or both, whether you get error messages and what those error messages say, what process you do - what do you select and what you see or not see and post images to show the problem. Obviously not all of these things may apply in this case, but I'm sure you get the general idea.

What is the exact problem? this is an example of how to tell someone about a problem.

Problem : My Unified Inbox does not show emails for all mail account Inboxes

Fix:

  • Right click on 'Unified Inbox' folder and select 'Properties'
  • click on 'Choose'
  • Make sure the checkbox for 'Inbox' is selected for all accounts including 'Local Folders'
  • click on 'OK'
  • click on 'Update'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
In 'Addons & Themes'

What 'Theme' are you using - 'Dark' or 'Light' or 'System Theme' ?

In 'Extensions' - what addon extensions have you installed ?


re: Also I change the layout and next time I open Thunderbird it has deleted my selection.

That sounds like either something is not getting updated or something is deleting session files so they cannot update files on exit. In the past I've come across products like CCleaner which clean up files and they can cause havoc.

1. Do not allow any Anti-Virus or malware type of product or any thing like CCleaner or WiseCleaner to have access to your thunderbird profile folders. Please Exit Thunderbird and then access those type of products and make Thunderbird an exemption not to scan that folder or anything it contains. Your 'Thunderbird' profile folder is located here - assuming you are using Windows OS and profile is in default location.

  • C://Users/User name/Appdata/Roaming/Thunderbird

If you did have those products scanning etc then maybe it will fix the loss of session and updating of files.

2. However in addition you can safely do the following just in case you have some corrupted files. It recreates them upon restart.

In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Under 'Application Basics' - half way -Profile Folder - click on 'Open Folder'

It will open in a new window showing you the contents of your profile name folder.

  • Exit Thunderbird now.

Delete the following files:

  • global-messages-db.sqlite
  • session.json
  • xulstore.json

Start Thunderbird.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
It would be useful to post an image showing the problem.

The 'Send' button will be replaced by the 'Send Later' button if you are in offline mode. The 'Send' button will be greyed out until you enter a TO email address. The 'Send' button should be on the 'Composition Toolbar', but do you see the 'Composition Toolbar' ? If you see the 'Composition Toolbar' and use right click to select 'Customize': Did you click on the 'Restore default set' button ?


Do you use any Addon extensions in Thunderbird? In Addons & Themes ? Select 'Extensions What addon are listed whether enabled or disabled?

Are you using the Thunderbird default 'Light' or 'Dark' theme or are you using the 'System theme' or have you downloaded a different theme?

In Thunderbird

  • Close any Write windows that are open.
  • Help > Troubleshoot mode
  • Click on 'Restart'
  • select checkbox 'Reset Toolbar and Controls'
  • Click on 'Make changes and restart'

creator: paul577

content:
Thunderbird has two options to increase/decrease spacing and increase/decrease font size.

Spacing Via 'Menu Bar' toolbar

  • 'View' > 'Density' > 'Compact' or 'Default' or 'Relaxed'

Via 'Menu app' icon

  • 'Menu app icon' > 'Density' > 3 icons left to right representing 'Compact' 'Default' 'Relaxed'

Font Size Via 'Menu Bar' toolbar

  • 'View' > 'Font Size' > 'increase font size' - repeat click to incrementally increase size

Via 'Menu app' icon

  • 'Menu app icon' > 'Font Size' - click on the + icon to increase size

The above will effect the general UI of Thunderbird.

The Message Pane and compose Write area can be effected as well but it will depend upon any separate font size etc choices made in:

  • Settings > General
  • 'Language & Appearance'
  • 'Fonts & Colors' - click on 'Advanced'
  • Choose options for both Fonts for 'Latin' and 'Other Writing Systems' and any additional language eg: cyrillic

If general UI is set up to 12px and Message Pane/Compose set up to 16px then you may find a general increase in UI Font Size to 14px will not effect Message Pane as it has been set to a higher px value.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Grazie Next!

Per quanto riguarda la disposizione di titolo-mittente-data ho immediatamente risolto grazie alle indicazioni presenti nel link che mi hai fornito, ottimo, adesso si che mi ritrovo!

Invece seguendo le tue indicazioni nulla da fare per la dimensione dei caratteri dei messaggi che rimangono ora immutati qualsiasi dimensione imposto.

Credo di aver trovato parte dell'inghippo, probabilmente non riesco piú a cambiare la dimensione dei caratteri dei messaggi (in nessun modo) perché ho impostato l'apertura dei messaggi in una nuova scheda/finestra anziché a lato dell'elenco (con l'impostazione a lato dell'elenco cambiavano le dimensioni assieme a quelle dell'elenco, come detto nel post di apertura).

Riesco, ma con lo stesso risultato dello zoom, ovvero nella finestra/scheda del messaggio Visualizza>dimensione carattere>aumenta dimensione carattere

Ma, appunto, vale solo per quel singolo messaggio e chiudendolo quando lo riapro é tornato piccolo, il tasto "reimposta dimensione del carattere" invece non sortisce alcun effetto (sembra non funzionare proprio).

Possibile che se i messaggi si aprono in una nuova finestra/scheda non si possano impostare le dimensioni dei caratteri permanentemente e per tutti i messaggi?

Caratteri che peró non credo siano quelli default in quanto se spunto la casella "utilizza caratteri a larghezza fissa per i messaggi in testo semplice" gli stessi diventano molto piú piccoli, forse come erano di default.

Possibile che rimangano le impostazioni effettuate quando i messaggi si aprivano a lato dell'elenco (non ricordo piú come tornare alla visualizzazione a lato per provare)?

Curioso il fatto che i caratteri dell'intestazione dei messaggi invece si adeguino alle stesse dimensioni dell'elenco che imposto pur essendo in una nuova scheda/finestra...é solo il testo del messaggio che non ne vuole sapere.
creator: aconita

content:
Non mi trovo molto bene con la nuova versione di Thunderbird (115), preferivo come era prima. lo trovo scomodo, preferivo: titolo-mittente-data

Segui le indicazioni discusse qui -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/questions/1426855

Mi piacerebbe anche poter cambiare la dimensione dei caratteri dei soli messaggi aperti ma non di tutto l'elenco.

Menu > Impostazioni > Generale Sezione Lingua e aspetto > Caratteri e colori > [Avanzate] Dim. Minima del carattere Qui inserisci un valore che ritieni opportuno. Poi togli la spunta da Consenti ai messaggi di utilizzare altri caratteri
creator: @next
